Zero-Pi Qubit (decoupled from zeta mode)¶

The Zero-Pi qubit [Brooks2013] [Dempster2014], when decoupled from the zeta mode, is described by the Hamiltonian

\[\begin{split}H &= -2E_\text{CJ}\partial_\phi^2+2E_{\text{C}\Sigma}(i\partial_\theta-n_g)^2 +2E_{C\Sigma}dC_J\,\partial_\phi\partial_\theta\\ &\qquad -2E_\text{J}\cos\theta\cos(\phi-\varphi_\text{ext}/2)+E_L\phi^2+2E_\text{J} + E_J dE_J \sin\theta\sin(\phi-\phi_\text{ext}/2)\end{split}\]

expressed in phase basis. The definition of the relevant charging energies \(E_\text{CJ}\), \(E_{\text{C}\Sigma}\), Josephson energies \(E_\text{J}\), inductive energies \(E_\text{L}\), and relative amounts of disorder \(dC_\text{J}\), \(dE_\text{J}\) follows [Groszkowski2018].

Internally, the ZeroPi class formulates the Hamiltonian matrix by discretizing the phi variable, and using charge basis for the theta variable.

An instance of the Zero-Pi qubit is created as follows:

phi_grid = sc_qubits.Grid1d(-6*np.pi, 6*np.pi, 200)

zero_pi = sc_qubits.ZeroPi(grid = phi_grid,
                           EJ   = 0.25,
                           EL   = 10.0**(-2),
                           ECJ  = 0.5,
                           EC   = None,
                           ECS  = 10.0**(-3),
                           ng   = 0.1,
                           flux = 0.23,
                           ncut = 30)

Here, flux is given in dimensionless units, in the form \(2\pi\Phi_\text{ext}/\Phi_0\). In the above example, the disorder parameters dEJ and dCJ are not specified, and hence take on the default value zero (no disorder).

Calculational methods related to Hamiltonian and energy spectra¶

sc_qubits.ZeroPi.hamiltonian(self)

sc_qubits.ZeroPi.eigenvals(self[, …])

Calculates eigenvalues using scipy.linalg.eigh, returns numpy array of eigenvalues.

sc_qubits.ZeroPi.eigensys(self[, …])

Calculates eigenvalues and corresponding eigenvectors using scipy.linalg.eigh.

sc_qubits.ZeroPi.get_spectrum_vs_paramvals(…)

Calculates eigenvalues for a varying system parameter, given an array of parameter values.

Wavefunctions and visualization of eigenstates¶

sc_qubits.ZeroPi.wavefunction(self[, esys, …])

sc_qubits.ZeroPi.plot_wavefunction(self[, …])

Different modes: ‘abs_sqr’: \(|\psi|^2\) ‘abs’: \(|\psi|\) ‘real’: \(\text{Re}(\psi)\) ‘imag’: \(\text{Im}(\psi)\)

Implemented operators¶

The following operators are implemented for use in matrix element calculations.

sc_qubits.ZeroPi.i_d_dphi_operator(self)

sc_qubits.ZeroPi.phi_operator(self)

sc_qubits.ZeroPi.n_theta_operator(self)

sc_qubits.ZeroPi.cos_theta_operator(self)

sc_qubits.ZeroPi.sin_theta_operator(self)

Todo

may want to implement additional ops

Computation and visualization of matrix elements¶

sc_qubits.ZeroPi.matrixelement_table(self, …)

Returns table of matrix elements for operator with respect to the eigenstates of the qubit.

sc_qubits.ZeroPi.plot_matrixelements(self, …)

Plots matrix elements for operator, given as a string referring to a class method that returns an operator matrix.

sc_qubits.ZeroPi.get_matelements_vs_paramvals(…)

Calculates matrix elements for a varying system parameter, given an array of parameter values.

sc_qubits.ZeroPi.plot_matelem_vs_paramvals(…)

Generates a simple plot of a set of eigenvalues as a function of one parameter.

Utility method for setting charging energies¶

sc_qubits.ZeroPi.set_EC_via_ECS(self, ECS)

Helper function to set EC by providing ECS, keeping ECJ constant.
Brooks2013

Brooks et al., Phys. Rev. A 87, 052306 (2013)

Dempster2014

Dempster et al., Phys. Rev. B 90, 094518 (2014)

Groszkowski2018

Groszkowski et al., New J. Phys. 20, 043053 (2018).
